Main features: Thinner (3.3 mm), flash only, now up to 512 Gigabyte, although standard goes up to 128 Gigabyte since CF 5.0Gigabyte
Thicker (5.0 mm), older flash, but usually Microdrive, up to 128 PiBMicrodrive
XQD form factor (38.5 mm × 29.8 mm), PCIe 3.0 x2 (2,0 GB/s), NVMe
PCIe 3.0 x8 (8,0 GB/s), NVMe
Very slim (45.0×37.0×0.76 mm), no Wear leveling controller, up to 128 MB. This particular example shows the write protect sticker (the silver disc).
Slim and small (24×32×1.4 mm), up to 16 GB
Compact (24×18×1.4 mm), up to 16 GB
Compact (24×32×1.4 mm), swifter, optional DRM, up to 16 GB
Subcompact (14×12×1.1 mm), optional DRM, 16 MB to 4 GB
Small (32×24×2.1 mm), DRM, up to 4 GB. (2 GB and 4 GB cards use larger block sizes and may not be compatible with some host devices. See Secure digital)
Compact (21.5×20×1.4 mm), DRM, up to 4 GB. (2 GB and 4 GB cards use larger block sizes and may not be compatible with some host devices. See Secure digital)
Subcompact (15×11×1 mm), DRM, up to 4 GB. (2 GB and 4 GB cards use larger block sizes and may not be compatible with some host devices. See Secure digital)
Same build as SD but greater capacity and transfer speed, 4 GB to 32 GB (not compatible with older host devices).
Same build as miniSD but greater capacity and transfer speed, 4 GB to 32 GB. 8 GB is largest in early-2011 (not compatible with older host devices).
Same build as microSD but greater capacity and transfer speed, 4 GB to 32 GB.[3](not compatible with older host devices)
Same build as SD/SDHC, but greater capacity and transfer speed, 32 GB and higher. Standard goes up to 2 TB (not compatible with older host devices).
Same build as microSD/microSDHC, but greater capacity and transfer speed, 32 GB and higher. Standard goes up to 2 TB (not compatible with older host devices).
Same build as SD/SDHC/SDXC, but greater capacity and transfer speed. Standard goes up to 128 TB (not compatible with older host devices).
Same build as microSD/microSDHC/microSDXC, but greater capacity and transfer speed. Standard goes up to 128 TB (not compatible with older host devices)
Slim and narrow (50×21.5×2.8 mm), optional DRM, up to 128 MB
Slim and narrow (50×21.5×2.8 mm), swifter, optional DRM, up to 4 GB
Compact (31×20×1.6 mm), optional DRM, up to 128 MB
Compact (31×20×1.6 mm), optional DRM, up to 32 GB
Compact (31×20×1.6 mm), swifter, optional DRM, up to 32 GB
Subcompact (15×12.5×1.2 mm), optional DRM, up to 16 GB
Subcompact (15×12.5×1.6 mm[4]), compulsory DRM, up to 64 GB, proprietary (can be used on PS Vita only)
High-capacity, high-speed standard using PCIe as interface
Slim and small (20×25×1.78 mm), electrically identical to SmartMedia, no wear-leveling controller, up to 512 MB[5]
Slim and small (20×25×1.78 mm) but slower read/write, no wear-leveling controller, up to 2 GB[5]
Slim and small (20×25×1.78 mm) and swifter, no wear-leveling controller, up to 2 GB[5]

Packages the flash memory, currently soldered in shipping smartphones, into a removable card form factor. Uses the SCSI command set including queuing. The electrical interface makes use of Differential signaling, which enables high bus speeds and robustness under noisy conditions and reduced pin count (compared to parallel bus alternatives such as Differential signaling).
Universally compatible across most non-mobile computer platforms, their greater size suits them better to file transfer/storage instead of use in portable devices
